chapter.title: Manage organisation units
chapter.para: In this section you will learn how to:

listitem.para: Create a new organisation unit and build up the organisation unit hierarchy
Create organisation unit groups, group sets, and assigning organisation units to them
Modify the organisation unit hierarchy

section.title: Organisation units overview
section.para: The organisation unit hierarchy defines the organisation structure of DHIS 2, for example how the health facilities, administrative areas and other geographical areas are arranged with respect to each other. It is essentially the "where" dimension of DHIS 2, similar to how periods represent the "when" or time dimension. DHIS 2 is structured so that the organisational unit hierarchy is a geographical hierarchy, and the GIS module depends on this. Non-geographical hierarchies are discouraged,. It is recommended to represent them by using organisational unit groups. This dimension to the data is defined as a hierarchy with one root unit (for example Ministry of Health or a country) and any number of levels and nodes below. Each node in this hierarchy is called an organisational unit in DHIS 2.

The design of the organisation unit hierarchy determines the geographical units of analysis available to the users as data is collected and aggregated in this structure. You can only have one organisational hierarchy at the same time so you must carefully plan its structure.

You can create additional hierarchies (for example parallel administrative boundaries to the health care sector) by using organisational groups and group sets. The organisational hierarchy is the main vehicle for data aggregation on the geographical dimension. Typically national organisational hierarchies in public health have four to six levels, but DHIS 2 supports any number of levels.

The organisation unit hierarchy is built up of parent-child relations. A country might for example have eight provinces, and each province might have a number of districts as children. Normally the health facilities (from which data is typically collected) will be located at the lowest level, but they can also be located at higher levels, for example national or provincial hospitals. Therefore, skewed organisational trees are supported (for example a leaf node can be positioned at level 2 while most other leaf nodes are at level 5).

important.para: It is easy to make changes to the upper levels of the hierarchy. at a later stage, the only problem is changing organisational units that collect data (the leaf nodes), for example splitting or merging health facilities. Aggregation up the hierarchy is done based on the current hierarchy at any time and will always reflect the most recent changes to the organisational structure.

Because the most recent information which is contained in the organisational unit hierarchy is always used for aggregation, it is important to keep in mind that changes to it (such as the division of districts into two separate districts) will not be respected over time. As an example, District A may be sub-divided into District B and District C. This is a process which often happens for political reasons. Facilities which belong to District A would need to be reassigned to District B and C. However, any historical data, which was entered before the split actually occurred, would still be registered as belonging to District B and C and not the defunct District A. This temporal representation of the organisational hierarchy across time will be lost.

section.para: In the Organisation units section of the Maintenance app, you can manage the following organisation unit objects:

table.title: Organisation unit objects in the Maintenance app

entry.para: Create, edit, clone, delete, show details and translate
Create, edit, clone, share, delete, show details and translate
Create, edit, clone, share, delete, show details and translate

section.title: Workflow
section.para: The recommended workflow is
To avoid such situations it is recommend to first add groups to group sets, and then organisation units to groups.

section.title: Create an organisation unit
section.para: You add organisation units one by one as either a root unit or a child of a selected organisation unit.

The organisation unit tree to the left represents the current organisational unit hierarchy. If you select a unit in this tree, you will see its children in the list in the middle of the screen. When you have selected an organisation unit in the left side organisation tree, you can also add new children to it.

note.para: The search function displays only exact matches, it is case-insensitive.

section.para: To add a new root organisation unit make sure no organisation unit is selected in the menu and click on "Add new".
To create a new organisation unit:

listitem.para: Click Apps > Maintenance > Organisation units > Organisation Unit.
Select the organisation unit you want to add the new organisation unit to.
You can locate the organisation unit in the tree by expanding the branches (click on the arrow symbol), or by searching for it by name or code.
Click the yellow plus button.
In the Name field, define the precise name of the organisation unit.
Each organisation unit must have a unique name.
In the Short name field, define a short name for the organisation unit.
Typically, the short name is an abbreviation of the full organisation unit name. This attribute is often used in reports to display the name of the organisation unit, where space is limited.
(Optional) In the Code field, assign a code.
In many countries organisation units are assigned a code.
In the Description field, type a description of the organisation unit.
Select an Opening date.
The opening dates control which organisation units that where existing at a point in time, for example when analysing historical data. This attribute is mandatory.
The default date for opening of organisation units is 1900-01-01, but you can set it to any date even to a date that occurs in the future.
If applicable, select a Closed date.
In the Comment field, enter any additional information that you would like to add.
(Optional) In the URL field, enter a link to an external web site that has additional information about the organisation unit.
Enter contact information:
Contact person
Address
E-mail
Phone number
This information can be vital for facilitating follow-up.
Enter a HR identifier.
If applicable, enter custom attributes values.
If you have added attributes to organisation units, they are visible in the Create new organisation unit pane. You set these attributes in Data Administration > Attribute.
For more information about how you can use attributes, refer to the "Attributes" section.
Click Save.

Registers data: This property is used to identify which organisation units that can register data or not. Sometimes administrative organisation units at higher levels in the hierarchy are not supposed to register any data. This can help control the data entry process as only organisation units with this property set to Yes will be available for data entry.

Coordinates: This field is used to create the maps in the GIS module. Paste in the coordinates of the organisation unit in this field, either a polygon (for organisation units that represent an administrative boundary) or a point (for health facilities). Without this information the GIS module will not work. It might be more efficient to import these coordinates later as a batch job for all organisation units using the import module. See the GIS chapter for more details.
Datasets: Datasets can be assigned to organisational units here. See the chapter on "Data sets" for more detailed information on assigning datasets to organisational units.
Organisation unit groups: Assignments to organisational units group sets can be assigned through the individual drop-down boxes which appear for each group set.

section.title: Create an organisation unit group
section.para: Organisation unit groups lets you classify related organisation units into a common theme. For example, might be grouped together into a organisation unit group "Example name".
To create a new organisation unit group:

listitem.para: Click Apps > Maintenance > Organisation units > Organisation Unit Group.
Click the yellow plus button.
Fill in the form:
Name: Provide a precise, unique and descriptive name for the organisation unit group.

Short name: The short name should be less than 25 characters. Typically, the short name is an abbreviation of the full organisation unit name. This attribute is used in certain places in DHIS 2 where space is limited.
Symbol: Select a symbol which will be used to display the organisation unit (points only) when the layer is displayed in the GIS app.
In the organisation tree, click the organisation units you want to group.
The selected organisation units display in orange.
Datasets: If you assign a dataset to an organisational unit group, all organisation units which are currently assigned to the dataset will be also present in this organisation unit group.
Click Save.

section.title: Create an organisation unit group set
section.para: Group sets is a flexible tool to add more categorisation to organisation units. You can have any number of group sets in a ?? DHIS instance/project??. By default, all databases have two group sets:

listitem.para: Type
Ownership

section.para: The organisation unit group sets makes reporting and analysis easier within DHIS 2. Using these group sets will simplify how reporting is done, and facilitate analysis through the use of tools as for example Excel PivotTables.

While a group set like "Type" describes a measure dimension, the actual categories are represented by the groups, and the categorisation of an organisation unit through the organisation unit's group memberships. This can be understood as a parallel hierarchy of organisation units with the group set as the root ("Type"), the groups at level 2 (e.g. "Clinic", "Hospital", "Dispensary"), and the actual organisation units at level 3. The group set can as such provide additional information and dimensionality to the data analysis as data is easily filtered, organised, or aggregated by groups within a group set.
For this aggregation to work without any duplication in the data some rules are necessary:

listitem.para: A group set is always exclusive, which means that an organisation unit cannot be member of more than one group in a group set. Therefore, when creating a new organisational unit, you will only be allowed to select a single organisational group membership for each group set.

It is possible to define whether a group set is compulsory or not, which will affect the completeness of the data when analysing data using group sets. Compulsory means that ALL organisation units must be member of a group in that group set.

section.para: It is recommend that you approach the organisation unit grouping in the following sequence (and one group set at a time):

listitem.para: Define a new group set, for example "Location".
Add new groups (such as "Urban", "Rural" and "Peri-urban"). Once all groups have been defined, return to the organisational unit group set and assign each of the desired groups to the group set.

Go back to each group, one by one, go to edit mode and assign the organisation units that should be member of the group. Should you follow this route, you can place multiple organisation units at a time in a group. However, you must be careful not to place the same organisational units in two groups which itself is a member of an organisation unit group set. This will result in a data integrity violation. If you have organisation unit groups which are not exclusive, they should not be members of a group.

A better way to ensure that you do not mistakenly assign an organisation unit to multiple members of a group set is you can use the edit feature of each organisational unit to assign memberships to each group set. You will only be able to assign a single organisation unit at a time however.

section.para: It is important to keep in mind when using the "Organisational unit group" set function, that unless great care is taken, organisational units can be assigned to multiple groups of a group set. This can be checked through the "Data Integrity" module, which will report which organisational units are not members of a compulsory organisational unit group set, and which organisational units have been assigned to more than one member of a group set.
To create an organisation unit group set:

listitem.para: Click Apps > Maintenance > Organisation units > Organisation Unit Group Set.
Click the yellow plus button.
Fill in the form:
Name: Provide a precise name for the organisation unit group set.
Description: Describe the phenomena the organisation unit group set is measuring or capturing.
If ALL organisation units must be members of a group in this group set, select Compulsory.
Data dimension
Select organisation unit groups and assign them.

Available organisation unit groups are displayed in the left panel. Organisation unit groups that are currently members of the organisation unit group set are displayed in the right hand panel. Use the arrows to move selected groups between the two lists.
If no groups appear in the list then you must go to Organisation Unit Groups and create new groups first.

note.para: It is not possible to assign groups that violate the exclusive rule on group sets. For example adding a group that already has assigned an organisation unit that again is already member of a group that has already been selected by this group set, will not be possible since one organisation unit will end up with two group memberships in the same group set.
To avoid such situations it is recommend to first add groups to group sets, and then organisation units to groups.

listitem.para: Click Save.

section.title: Edit organisation units and other objects

listitem.para: Click Apps > Maintenance > Organisation units.
Select the object type you want to edit, for example organisation unit or organisation unit group.
In the list, find the object you want to modify.
Click the options menu and select Edit.
Modify the options you want.
Click Save.

section.title: Clone organisation units and other objects
section.para: Cloning a organisation unit can save time when you create many similar organisation units which differ in only a few details.

listitem.para: Click Apps > Maintenance > Organisation units.
Select the object type you want to clone, for example organisation unit or organisation unit group.
In the list, find the object you want to modify.
Click the options menu and select Clone.
Modify the options you want.
Click Save.

section.title: Change sharing settings for organisation unit groups and group sets

listitem.para: Click Apps > Maintenance > Organisation units.
Select Organisation unit group or Organisation unit group set.
In the list, find the object you want to modify.
Click the options menu and select Share.
Modify the options you want.
Click Close.

section.title: Delete organisation units and other objects

listitem.para: Click Apps > Maintenance > Organisation units.
Select the object type you want to delete, for example organisation unit or organisation unit group.
In the list, find the object you want to delete.
Click the options menu and select Delete.
Click OK to confirm.

section.title: Display details of organisation units and other objects

listitem.para: Click Apps > Maintenance > Organisation units.
Select the object type you want to display, for example organisation unit or organisation unit group.
In the list, find the object you want to view.
To display all metadata about the selected object, click the options menu and select Show details.

section.title: Translate organisation units and other objects
section.para: DHIS 2 provides functionality for translations of database content like data elements, data element groups, indicators, indicator groups, validation rules and more. You can translate these elements to any number of locales. A locale represents a specific geographical, political, or cultural region.

tip.para: To activate a translation, go to Apps > Settings > Appearance and select a language.

listitem.para: Click Apps > Maintenance > Organisation units.
Select the object type you want to translate, for example organisation unit or organisation unit group.
In the list, find the object you want to translate.
Click the options menu and select Translate.
If you want to translate an organisation unit level, click directly on the Translate icon next to each list item.
Select a locale.
Enter Name, Short name, Description and Form name.
Click Close.

section.title: Assign names to organisation unit levels
section.para: You can specify a contextual name for each level in the hierarchy, for example "Country", "Province", "District" or "Health Facility". The contextual names are used all over the application where levels are referred to. This page will take some time to load if the organisation unit hierarchy is very big.

listitem.para: Click Apps > Maintenance > Organisation units > Organisation unit level.
Task 2
Task 3

section.title: Move organisation units within a hierarchy
section.para: You can move organisation units around in the hierarchy by changing the parent of a selected organisation unit.

listitem.para: Click Apps > Maintenance > Organisation units > Hierarchy operations.
Select the organisation units you want to move:
In the hierarchy tree to the left, select the organisation unit you want to move.
In the hierarchy tree to the right, select where you want to move the organisation unit to.
Repeat selection for all the organisation units you want to move.
Click Move x organisation units, where x stands for the number of organisation units you have selected.
Your changes are immediately reflected in the left side hierarchy tree.
